then.name: Anomalous Connection::Unusual Admin RDP Session
then.description:
A highly privileged credential is being used to connect between two devices that rarely interact.

Action: Review the credential to see where it has been active recently. Review the device to see what other behaviours it is performing, for example if an admin has logged on remotely to fix a technical issue.

now.name: Anomalous Connection::Unusual Admin RDP Session
now.description:
A highly privileged credential is being used to connect between two devices that rarely interact.

Action: Review the credential to see where it has been active recently. Review the device to see what other behaviours it is performing, for example if an admin has logged on remotely to fix a technical issue.

data.description: A device that has been inactive for at least 4 weeks has re-appeared on the network in the past 48 hours.

trigger.value: Client connected with this RDP cookie, result=encrypted

then.name: Anomalous Connection::Multiple HTTP POSTs to Rare Hostname
then.description:
A device is posting data out of the network to a rare external hostname. Posting data with the HTTP POST method can be used to send unencrypted data to remote servers. The method is often abused by attackers as a way of exfiltrating data via a Trojan or other remote access malware, and therefore unusual data uploads of this type may be an indicator of compromise.

Action: Investigate the external endpoint to determine if this activity relates to malicious communications. Consider downloading PCAP to see the data that was sent. If the connections are not for a legitimate purpose, this is a strong indication of an active malware infection.

now.name: Anomalous Connection::Multiple HTTP POSTs to Rare Hostname
now.description:

The method is often abused by attackers as a way of exfiltrating data via a Trojan or other remote access malware, and therefore unusual data uploads of this type may be an indicator of compromise.

Action: Investigate the external endpoint to determine if this activity relates to malicious communications. Consider downloading PCAP to see the data that was sent. If the connections are not for a legitimate purpose, this is a strong indication of an active malware infection.

then.name: Compliance::SSH to Rare External Destination
then.description:
A device is making SSH connections to rare external destinations. While external SSH connections will likely occur in most networks, these should be few and regular. New or unusual SSH destinations are interesting as they could be used for exfiltration and may raise compliance issues.

Action: Investigate the destination being connected to and see if it is a known device that would be used for business purposes.

now.name: Compliance::SSH to Rare External Destination
now.description:
A device is making SSH connections to rare external destinations. While external SSH connections will likely occur in most networks, these should be few and regular. New or unusual SSH destinations are interesting as they could be used for exfiltration and may raise compliance issues.

Action: Investigate the destination being connected to and see if it is a known device that would be used for business purposes.

then.name: Device::Attack and Recon Tools
then.description:
A device is using common penetration testing tools.

Action: Review the device to see if it a security device, these can be tagged as such to exclude them from future breaches. Activity from non security devices merit further investigation into what else the device is doing and could be a significant risk within the network.

then.name: Device::Network Scan
then.description:
A device is making new internal connections to a range of internal hosts consistent with network scanning. Unauthorised network scanning is a common symptom of network worms attempting to propagate.

Action: Review the device and if it is a known security device it can be tagged as such to exclude the activity from future breaches.

now.name: Device::Network Scan
now.description:
A device is making new internal connections to a range of internal hosts consistent with network scanning. Unauthorised network scanning is a common symptom of network worms attempting to propagate.

Action: Review the device and if it is a known security device it can be tagged as such to exclude the activity from future breaches.

then.name: Anomalous Connection::Unusual Internal Connections
then.description:
A device is making a far larger than normal volume of internal connections. This can occur during network scanning and brute force attacks.

Action: Use the breach log and device event log to investigate which devices the connections are occurring between. Visualise connection history to see if they regularly communicate.

then.name: System::New Subnet Detected
then.description:
Traffic from a new subnet has been detected. This can happen when a master is seeing traffic from a subnet range it has not previously modelled.

Action: Use Advanced Search to identify the traffic being seen, and if it is expected. For example, if you have an alert on 10.101.65.0/24, you can search for 10.101.65.* (all IP's in the /24 subnet). Looking at the connection UUID's can help to pinpoint the source of traffic. The last two numbers signify the device the traffic was seen on. For example C5MH9EnfzLXP9N900 would be from device 00 (the master).

now.name: System::New Subnet Detected
now.description:

For example, if you have an alert on 10.101.65.0/24, you can search for 10.101.65.* (all IP's in the /24 subnet). Looking at the connection UUID's can help to pinpoint the source of traffic. The last two numbers signify the device the traffic was seen on. For example C5MH9EnfzLXP9N900 would be from device 00 (the master).

then.name: Compromise::Slow Beaconing Activity To External Rare
then.description:
A device has been repeatedly connecting to a rare external location with a beacon score. A beacon score is added when Darktrace identifies that a device is regularly communicating with an endpoint, for example, if a device connects to a rare external endpoint every 12 minutes this would get a beacon score. This model is designed to identify beaconing at a lower threshold and be protocol agnostic.

Action: Review the external domains and IPs being connected to to see if they are legitimate and would be expected for business purposes.

now.name: Compromise::Slow Beaconing Activity To External Rare
now.description:
A device has been repeatedly connecting to a rare external location with a beacon score. A beacon score is added when Darktrace identifies that a device is regularly communicating with an endpoint, for example, if a device connects to a rare external endpoint every 12 minutes this would get a beacon score. This model is designed to identify beaconing at a lower threshold and be protocol agnostic.

Action: Review the external domains and IPs being connected to to see if they are legitimate and would be expected for business purposes.

then.description:
A device is making an unusual outgoing Secure Shell (SSH) connection. SSH is commonly used by administrators to remotely manage devices but in this case the devices do not normally communicate in this way.

Action: Consider whether the device should be performing administrative activities and look at other recent breaches from this device for signs of compromise.

then.name: System::Capture Loss on Appliance
then.description:
At least 2 capture loss notices higher than 30% have been seen across 24 hours, across all physical appliances. The capture loss indicates the percentage of ACKs seen where the data being ACKed was not seen. Sustained capture loss at or above this level will significantly impact Darktrace detections. This model indicates the packet loss is occurring before Darktrace ingestion rather than a problem with the appliance.

Action: Investigate whether this is due to one appliance or whether multiple appliances have contributed to the model breach. The query below can be used in Advanced Search to filter for appliance capture loss notices greater than 30%. @fields.host can be grouped by selecting 'Score' to view the top contributors by appliance:
@fields.note:"CaptureLoss::Too_Much_Loss" AND @fields.size:>29 AND @fields.msg:*dt*
The appliance console can then be used to view interface stats to see if the 1Gb / 10 Gb analysis cables are reaching their limit. If this is reasonable, there is likely a loss occurring upstream on the switch SPAN session(s). Please consult with the switch vendor if you expect this to be the case.

now.name: System::Capture Loss on Appliance

This model indicates the packet loss is occurring before Darktrace ingestion rather than a problem with the appliance.

Action: Investigate whether this is due to one appliance or whether multiple appliances have contributed to the model breach. The query below can be used in Advanced Search to filter for appliance capture loss notices greater than 30%. @fields.host can be grouped by selecting 'Score' to view the top contributors by appliance:
@fields.note:"CaptureLoss::Too_Much_Loss" AND @fields.size:>29 AND @fields.msg:*dt*
The appliance console can then be used to view interface stats to see if the 1Gb / 10 Gb analysis cables are reaching their limit. If this is reasonable, there is likely a loss occurring upstream on the switch SPAN session(s). Please consult with the switch vendor if you expect this to be the case.

then.name: Compliance::Default Credential Usage
then.description:
A username, which is used for default Vendor credentials, is being used on the network. Such credentials are often targeted by malicious actors for compromise.

Action: Confirm that the account in question is using strong, non-default passwords. Also consider using non-standard usernames.

Action: Use the breach log and device event log to investigate where the data is being sent to / from and whether it could contain sensitive information.

then.name: Compromise::Watched Domain
then.description:
A device is observed making DNS requests or connections to watched domains or IP addresses. The watch list can be edited from the main GUI menu, Intel sub-menu, under the icon Watched Domains.

Action: Review the domain and IP being connected to.

then.name: Anomalous Connection::Rare External SSL Self-Signed
then.description:
A device is communicating with a server using a self signed certificate. This is a particular threat if the certificate is attempting to impersonate legitimate services.

Action: Investigate the endpoint being connected to. Self signed certificates are often used by malware communications and ill reputed web servers.

then.name: Device::Network Scan
then.description:
A device is making new internal connections to a range of internal hosts consistent with network scanning. Unauthorised network scanning is a common symptom of network worms attempting to propagate.

Action: Review the device and if it is a known security device it can be tagged as such to exclude the activity from future breaches.

then.name: Device::ICMP Address Scan
then.description:
A device is making new internal connections to a range of internal hosts via ICMP, consistent with network scanning. ICMP is a lightweight protocol used to scope host and router addresses within a network.

Action: Review the device and if it is a known security device it can be tagged as such to exclude the activity from future breaches. Unauthorised network scanning is a common symptom of network worms attempting to propagate.

then.description:
A device is sending RAR files out of the network.

Action: Review the files being sent to see if they contain any information about their contents in the name. Review the destination the files are being transferred to.

then.name: Compromise::Beaconing Activity To External Rare
then.description:
A device has been repeatedly connecting to a rare external location with a beacon score. A beacon score is added when Darktrace identifies that a device is regularly communicating with an endpoint, for example, if a device connects to a rare external endpoint every 12 minutes this would get a beacon score. This model is designed to identify beaconing at a lower threshold and be protocol agnostic.

Action: Review the external domains and IPs being connected to to see if they are legitimate and would be expected for business purposes.

now.name: Compromise::Beaconing Activity To External Rare
now.description:
A device has been repeatedly connecting to a rare external location with a beacon score. A beacon score is added when Darktrace identifies that a device is regularly communicating with an endpoint, for example, if a device connects to a rare external endpoint every 12 minutes this would get a beacon score. This model is designed to identify beaconing at a lower threshold and be protocol agnostic.

Action: Review the external domains and IPs being connected to to see if they are legitimate and would be expected for business purposes.

then.name: System::Capture Loss on Appliance
then.description:
At least 2 capture loss notices higher than 30% have been seen across 24 hours, across all physical appliances. The capture loss indicates the percentage of ACKs seen where the data being ACKed was not seen. Sustained capture loss at or above this level will significantly impact Darktrace detections. This model indicates the packet loss is occurring before Darktrace ingestion rather than a problem with the appliance.

Action: Investigate whether this is due to one appliance or whether multiple appliances have contributed to the model breach. The query below can be used in Advanced Search to filter for appliance capture loss notices greater than 30%. @fields.host can be grouped by selecting 'Score' to view the top contributors by appliance:
@fields.note:"CaptureLoss::Too_Much_Loss" AND @fields.size:>29 AND @fields.msg:*dt*
The appliance console can then be used to view interface stats to see if the 1Gb / 10 Gb analysis cables are reaching their limit. If this is reasonable, there is likely a loss occurring upstream on the switch SPAN session(s). Please consult with the switch vendor if you expect this to be the case.

then.name: Compromise::Uncommon Tor Usage
then.description:
A device appears to be communicating with the Tor network privacy service. Use of The Onion Router (Tor) can indicate a larger threat as this is not commonly used for legitimate business activities, but is commonly used for malicious purposes.

Action: Review the other breaches from this device. If the device doesn't need to communicate with Tor for business purposes remove the device from the network.

now.name: Compromise::Uncommon Tor Usage
now.description:
A device appears to be communicating with the Tor network privacy service. Use of The Onion Router (Tor) can indicate a larger threat as this is not commonly used for legitimate business activities, but is commonly used for malicious purposes.

Action: Review the other breaches from this device. If the device doesn't need to communicate with Tor for business purposes remove the device from the network.
now.message: Added new or uncommon occurrence display field

then.name: System::New Subnet Detected
then.description:
Traffic from a new subnet has been detected. This can happen when a master is seeing traffic from a subnet range it has not previously modelled.

Action: Use Advanced Search to identify the traffic being seen, and if it is expected. For example, if you have an alert on 10.101.65.0/24, you can search for 10.101.65.* (all IP's in the /24 subnet). Looking at the connection UUID's can help to pinpoint the source of traffic. The last two numbers signify the device the traffic was seen on. For example C5MH9EnfzLXP9N900 would be from device 00 (the master).

now.name: System::New Subnet Detected
now.description:
Traffic from a new subnet has been detected. This can happen when a master is seeing traffic from a subnet range it has not previously modelled.

Action: Use Advanced Search to identify the traffic being seen, and if it is expected. For example, if you have an alert on 10.101.65.0/24, you can search for 10.101.65.* (all IP's in the /24 subnet). Looking at the connection UUID's can help to pinpoint the source of traffic. The last two numbers signify the device the traffic was seen on. For example C5MH9EnfzLXP9N900 would be from device 00 (the master).

then.name: Device::Large Number of Connections to New Endpoints
then.description:
A device has initiated a large number of connections to unique, rare endpoints. This can be indicative of peer to peer activity, or worm activity such as scanning for EternalBlue exploit vulnerabilities.

Action: Investigate the endpoints and ports being connected to, to ascertain the nature of this activity. DNS requests around the time of the activity can indicate Torrent activity.

then.name: Unusual Activity::Multiple Failed Internal Connections
then.description:
A device has attempted and failed to make a number of internal connections within a short period.

Action: Investigate the internal destination to see if it is a legitimate activity and, if so, investigate why the device failed to connect to it.

then.name: Compromise::Domain Fluxing
then.description:
A device is connecting to multiple domains that do not appear to be human readable. This is an indication of a domain generation algorithm (DGA). This is commonly used in combination with large numbers of domains to allow a botnet to remain active despite domains being changed very quickly (domain fluxing).

Action: Review the domain requests to see if they are known to be legitimate, if not, it is likely the device is infected with malware.

now.name: Compromise::Domain Fluxing
